title: Clinical Hemodynamic Monitoring ‚Äî clinmon
text: data data data frame continuous monitoring data. First column must time seconds, followed physiological variables. time_var Time variable seconds. first column contain  continuous time measurements monitoring system. abp Arterial blood pressure measurements mmHg. Used calculating  multiple hemodynamic indices including PRx, Mx, Sx, Dx, CVRi, COest. mcav Middle cerebral artery blood velocity measurements. Used calculating Mx, Sx, Dx, CVRi, PI, RI indices. icp Intracranial pressure measurements mmHg. Used calculating PRx CPPopt indices combined arterial blood pressure. cpp Cerebral perfusion pressure measurements mmHg. Alternative ICP calculating Mx, Sx, Dx indices. hr Heart rate measurements beats per minute. Used calculating estimated cardiac output (COest). freq Frequency recorded data Hz. Default 1000 Hz high-resolution monitoring systems. Adjust based data collection frequency. blocksize Length block seconds. Blocks fundamental units calculating indices. Default 3 seconds. epochsize Size epochs number blocks. Epochs aggregate multiple blocks correlation-based indices. Default 20 blocks. output_level Select output row represent: - Period: Analysis periods (requires trigger data) - Epoch: Epoch-level results (correlation indices available) - Block: Block-level results (correlation indices) - CPPopt: Optimal cerebral perfusion pressure analysis overlapping Enable overlapping calculations correlation-based indices. can improve temporal resolution increases computation time. blockmin Minimum measurements required create block percentage. Blocks less data omitted. Default 50\ epochminMinimum blocks required create epoch percentage. Epochs fewer blocks omitted. Default 50\fast_processingEnable fast processing aggregating data analysis. speeds computation may reduce precision.show_summaryDisplay summary statistics calculated hemodynamic indices.show_detailedDisplay detailed results table calculated indices time period/epoch/block.   results object containing:

code: coefplot(   data,   dep = NULL,   covs = NULL,   model_type = "linear",   time_var = NULL,   include_intercept = FALSE,   coef_selection = "all",   specific_coefs = "",   ci_level = 0.95,   inner_ci_level = 0.8,   sort_coefs = "natural",   decreasing_sort = TRUE,   horizontal_plot = TRUE,   point_size = 3,   line_thickness = 1,   standardize = FALSE,   robust_se = FALSE,   exp_transform = FALSE,   compare_models = FALSE,   model2_covs = NULL,   model3_covs = NULL,   model_names = "Model 1, Model 2, Model 3",   show_coefficient_plot = TRUE,   show_model_summary = TRUE,   show_coefficient_table = FALSE,   custom_title = "",   custom_x_label = "" )

title: Coefficient Plots ‚Äî coefplot
text: data data data frame regression analysis. dep outcome variable regression analysis. Can continuous (linear regression), binary (logistic regression), time--event. covs Independent variables (predictors) include regression model. displayed coefficients plot. model_type Type regression model fit: - Linear: continuous outcomes - Logistic: binary outcomes (odds ratios) - Cox: survival analysis (hazard ratios) - Poisson: count outcomes (rate ratios) time_var Time--event variable Cox regression. required  model type set Cox regression. include_intercept Include intercept term coefficient plot. Usually  excluded often primary interest. coef_selection select coefficients display plot. specific_coefs Comma-separated list coefficient names include exclude  (depending selection method). Leave blank use coefficients. ci_level Confidence level coefficient confidence intervals (e.g., 0.95 95\ inner_ci_levelOptional inner confidence interval enhanced visualization. Set 0 disable inner CI. Common values 0.8 0.9. sort_coefsHow order coefficients plot. Magnitude sorting can help identify important predictors. decreasing_sortWhen sorting magnitude alphabetically, use decreasing order. horizontal_plotDisplay coefficients horizontally (default) vertically. Horizontal layout typically preferred readability. point_sizeSize coefficient points plot. line_thicknessThickness confidence interval lines. standardizeStandardize coefficients scaling predictors mean 0 SD 1. Useful comparing effect sizes across variables different scales. robust_seUse robust (sandwich) standard errors confidence intervals. Recommended concerns heteroscedasticity. exp_transformExponentiate coefficients show odds ratios (logistic), hazard ratios (Cox), rate ratios (Poisson). Automatically enabled logistic Cox models. compare_modelsCreate comparison plots multiple model specifications. Useful sensitivity analysis model selection. model2_covsCovariates second model comparison. used comparing models. model3_covsCovariates third model comparison. used comparing models. model_namesComma-separated names models comparing multiple models. used legend. show_coefficient_plotDisplay main coefficient plot confidence intervals. show_model_summaryDisplay statistical summary fitted model(s) including R-squared, AIC, fit statistics. show_coefficient_tableDisplay detailed table coefficients, standard errors, p-values. custom_titleCustom title coefficient plot. Leave blank automatic title. custom_x_labelCustom label x-axis. Leave blank automatic label based model type. results object containing:

code: comprehensiveSurvivalPower(   data,   method_category = "standard",   calculation_type = "sample_size",   statistical_method = "log_rank_schoenfeld",   study_design = "simple",   alpha = 0.05,   power = 0.8,   sample_size = 200,   allocation_ratio = 1,   hazard_ratio = 0.75,   median_survival_control = 12,   median_survival_treatment = 16,   accrual_period = 24,   follow_up_period = 36,   dropout_rate = 0.05,   event_rate = 0.6,   competing_event_rate = 0.2,   cumulative_incidence_control = 0.4,   cumulative_incidence_treatment = 0.3,   rmst_timepoint = 24,   non_inferiority_margin = 1.25,   superiority_test = FALSE,   snp_maf = 0.2,   genetic_model = "additive",   number_of_looks = 1,   spending_function = "lan_demets_obf",   show_detailed_output = TRUE,   show_sensitivity_analysis = FALSE,   show_power_curves = FALSE,   export_study_design = FALSE,   genetic_effect_size = 1.5,   cure_rate_control = 0,   cure_rate_treatment = 0,   survival_distribution = "exponential",   accrual_distribution = "uniform",   interim_futility_boundary = 0.2,   binding_futility = FALSE,   number_of_covariates = 2,   covariate_correlation = 0,   interaction_effect_size = 1,   covariate_distribution = "normal",   adjust_for_confounders = TRUE,   show_method_comparison = FALSE )

title: Comprehensive Survival Power Analysis (Expert) ‚Äî comprehensiveSurvivalPower
text: data data data frame (optional power calculations). method_category Choose category survival analysis method. Standard methods include log-rank tests Cox regression. Competing risks methods analyze multiple event types. Advanced methods include RMST, non-inferiority, specialized approaches. calculation_type Select parameter calculate. commonly used sample size (given desired power) power (given available sample size). statistical_method Choose specific statistical method. Available options depend selected method category. Schoenfeld method common log-rank tests. study_design Simple design assumes fixed follow-time. Complex design includes accrual period variable follow-. Sequential designs allow interim analyses. alpha Type error rate. Standard values: 0.05 (two-sided) 0.025 (one-sided). non-inferiority trials, consider 0.025. power Statistical power (probability detecting true effect). Standard values: 0.80 (80\ sample sizes. sample_size Total number subjects study. Used calculating power detectable effect size fixed sample size. allocation_ratio Ratio control treatment group sizes. 1.0 = equal allocation (1:1), 2.0 = twice many controls (2:1). Equal allocation efficient. hazard_ratio Expected hazard ratio. Values < 1 indicate treatment benefit. Common values: 0.75 (25\ (50\ median_survival_controlExpected median survival time control group. Units match study timeline (months, years, etc.). median_survival_treatmentExpected median survival time treatment group. longer control group beneficial treatments. accrual_periodTime period patient recruitment (months/years). Longer accrual periods allow smaller sample sizes extend study duration. follow_up_periodAdditional follow-time accrual completion. Total study duration = accrual period + follow-period. dropout_rateAnnual rate loss follow-(0.05 = 5\ Higher dropout rates require larger sample sizes maintain power. event_rateProportion subjects expected experience event study period. Used simple design calculations. competing_event_rateProportion experiencing competing events (competing risks analysis). less primary event rate. cumulative_incidence_controlExpected cumulative incidence primary event control group (competing risks analysis). cumulative_incidence_treatmentExpected cumulative incidence primary event treatment group (competing risks analysis). rmst_timepointTime point restricted mean survival time analysis. clinically meaningful within study follow-period. non_inferiority_marginNon-inferiority margin hazard ratio. 1.25 means treatment non-inferior HR < 1.25 (25\ acceptable). superiority_testAfter establishing non-inferiority, test superiority. Requires hierarchical testing approach control Type error. snp_mafMinor allele frequency SNP-based survival analysis. Common range: 0.05-0.45. genetic_modelGenetic inheritance model SNP analysis. Additive model common. number_of_looksNumber planned interim analyses sequential designs. looks require larger sample sizes maintain overall Type error. spending_functionMethod spending Type error across interim analyses. O'Brien-Fleming type preserves alpha final analysis. show_detailed_outputDisplay detailed calculation steps intermediate results. show_sensitivity_analysisPerform sensitivity analysis varying key parameters around specified values (+/- 10\show_power_curvesGenerate plots showing power vs sample size, effect size, parameters.export_study_designGenerate comprehensive study design document suitable protocols grant applications.genetic_effect_sizeGenetic effect size SNP-based survival analysis. Represents hazard ratio per copy risk allele.cure_rate_controlProportion subjects control group never experience event (cure fraction). 0 = cure, standard survival model.cure_rate_treatmentProportion subjects treatment group never experience event (cure fraction). Usually higher control group effective treatments.survival_distributionAssumed underlying survival distribution. Exponential assumes constant hazard; Weibull allows increasing/decreasing hazard; Piecewise allows complex patterns.accrual_distributionPattern patient enrollment time. Uniform = constant rate; Increasing/Decreasing = linear change; Exponential = curved pattern.interim_futility_boundaryFutility boundary interim analyses sequential designs. Probability threshold study may stopped futility.binding_futilityWhether futility boundaries binding (must stop crossed) non-binding (advisory ).number_of_covariatesNumber covariates include Cox regression model. covariates generally require larger sample sizes.covariate_correlationCorrelation covariates model. Higher correlation reduces effective sample size increases required sample size.interaction_effect_sizeEffect size interaction main exposure covariates. Used testing interaction effects.covariate_distributionDistribution type covariates model. Affects power calculations epidemiological studies.adjust_for_confoundersWhether account confounding variables power calculations. Generally recommended epidemiological studies.show_method_comparisonCompare results across multiple power calculation methods assess robustness sample size estimates.   results object containing:

title: Concordance Index (Harrell's C-index) ‚Äî concordanceindex
text: Harrell's concordance index (C-index) evaluating discrimination ability survival prediction models. C-index measures proportion comparable pairs patients model correctly ranks survival times - generalization ROC curve's AUC censored survival data. Values range 0.5 (discrimination) 1.0 (perfect discrimination), 0.7-0.8 considered good >0.8 considered excellent. Unlike time-dependent ROC evaluates specific time points, C-index provides global measure across entire follow-period. Supports time-dependent concordance dynamic predictions, competing risks extensions, stratified analysis, comparison models. Essential validating Cox regression models, machine learning survival predictions, prognostic scores. C-index accounts censoring appropriate pair weighting can decomposed identify risk groups contribute discrimination.

title: Concordance Index (Harrell's C-index) ‚Äî concordanceindex

title: Concordance Index (Harrell's C-index) ‚Äî concordanceindex
text: data data data frame. time Time--event censoring variable (days, months, years). time-dependent concordance, follow-time. event Binary event indicator (1 = event, 0 = censored). competing risks, can multi-level factor different event types. event_code level represents event interest (e.g., death, progression). predictor Continuous predictor variable used ranking patients. Can risk score, linear predictor Cox model, predicted probability. Higher values indicate higher risk (use reverse_direction option). reverse_direction predictor protective (lower values = higher risk), reverse direction concordance calculation. Example: survival probability lower values indicate worse prognosis. predictor_formula Formula Cox model predictor directly provided. Example: "~ age + stage + grade". Model fitted linear predictor used. cindex_method Method C-index calculation. Harrell's standard, Uno's uses inverse probability weighting censoring, G√∂nen-Heller bias-free estimator proportional hazards models (require follow-information). time_dependent Calculate time-dependent C-index specific time horizons. Evaluates discrimination predictions particular time points rather globally across follow-. evaluation_times Comma-separated time points time-dependent C-index evaluation. Example: "12, 24, 36, 60" 1, 2, 3, 5 years months. confidence_intervals Calculate confidence intervals C-index using bootstrap asymptotic standard errors. ci_method Method confidence interval estimation. Bootstrap accurate computationally intensive. bootstrap_samples Number bootstrap samples CI estimation. confidence_level Confidence level interval estimation. compare_models Compare C-index across multiple prediction models identify best discriminating model. additional_predictors Additional predictor variables (risk scores) model comparison. model_names Comma-separated names models compared. compare_test Perform statistical test differences C-index models. competing_risks Use competing risks framework C-index calculation multiple event types can occur. Requires cause-specific hazard approach. cause_specific competing risks, calculate cause-specific C-index event interest treating events censoring. decompose_cindex Decompose C-index show contribution different risk strata. Identifies patient groups contribute discrimination. risk_groups Number risk groups C-index decomposition (e.g., 3 = low/medium/high, 4 = quartiles, 10 = deciles). somers_d Calculate Somers' D rank correlation (D = 2*(C-index - 0.5)). Ranges -1 +1, interpretable correlation predictor outcome. goodman_kruskal_gamma Calculate Goodman-Kruskal gamma statistic ordinal association. Related C-index uses different pair weighting. stratified_cindex Calculate C-index stratified important subgroups assess consistency across populations. stratify_by Variable stratified analysis (e.g., treatment arm, center, age group). plot_cindex_over_time Plot time-dependent C-index across follow-period. Shows discrimination changes prediction horizon. plot_model_comparison Bar plot comparing C-index across multiple models confidence intervals. plot_risk_group_kaplan_meier Display Kaplan-Meier curves stratified risk groups defined predictor quantiles. Visual assessment separation = discrimination. plot_decomposition Visualize contribution different risk strata overall C-index. clinical_application Clinical application context interpretation guidance. show_interpretation Provide interpretation C-index clinical context recommendations. external_validation Indicate external validation (model different cohort). restricted_time Restrict C-index calculation specific follow-period avoid issues long-term censoring. max_time Maximum follow-time restricted C-index calculation. Pairs beyond time considered. handle_ties Method handling tied predictor values concordance calculation. missing_handling Method handling missing predictor outcome data. random_seed Random seed bootstrap stochastic procedures.

what: Conditional Inference Trees for Survival ‚Äî conditionalinference
title: Conditional Inference Trees for Survival ‚Äî conditionalinference
text: Conditional Inference Trees survival analysis using unbiased recursive partitioning. method addresses variable selection bias inherent traditional CART employing conditional inference procedures. algorithm separates variable selection splitting point selection, providing unbiased tree structures particularly valuable survival data mixed-type predictors complex censoring patterns. Features include statistical significance-based stopping criteria, handling  missing values without surrogate splits, robust performance correlated predictors. method particularly suitable exploratory survival analysis biomarker discovery clinical research.

title: Conditional Inference Trees for Survival ‚Äî conditionalinference
code: conditionalinference(   data,   time,   event,   predictors,   strata,   teststat = "quad",   testtype = "Bonferroni",   mincriterion = 0.95,   minsplit = 20,   minbucket = 7,   maxdepth = 5,   nresample = 9999,   logrank_scores = TRUE,   show_splits = TRUE,   show_nodes = TRUE,   show_importance = TRUE,   plot_tree = TRUE,   plot_survival = TRUE,   plot_importance = FALSE,   mtry,   replace = FALSE,   subset )

title: Conditional Inference Trees for Survival ‚Äî conditionalinference
text: data data data frame. time Time event variable (numeric). right-censored data,  time study entry event censoring. event Event indicator variable. survival analysis: 0 = censored, 1 = event. competing risks: 0 = censored, 1+ = different event types. predictors Variables use tree construction. Can include numeric,  ordinal, nominal variables. algorithm handles mixed-type predictors optimally. strata Optional stratification variable stratified survival analysis. Creates separate baseline hazards stratum. teststat Test statistic use. 'quad' uses quadratic form multivariate tests, 'max' uses maximum-type statistic. Quadratic form powerful small effects, maximum-type large effects. testtype Multiple testing correction method. Bonferroni provides conservative reliable correction. Monte Carlo uses permutation-based p-values. mincriterion Minimum criterion (1 - p-value) variable selection. Higher values create conservative trees fewer splits. Default 0.95 corresponds significance level 0.05. minsplit Minimum number observations required node splitting. Higher values create simpler trees reduce overfitting. minbucket Minimum number observations terminal nodes. smaller minsplit. Higher values increase tree stability. maxdepth Maximum depth tree. Controls tree complexity prevents overfitting. Deeper trees may overfit, shallower trees may underfit. nresample Number Monte Carlo resamples p-value computation using Monte Carlo test type. resamples provide accurate p-values increase computation time. logrank_scores Use log-rank scores survival splitting. TRUE, uses log-rank statistics optimized survival data. FALSE, uses standard conditional inference. show_splits Display detailed split statistics including test statistics, p-values, variable importance measures. show_nodes Display detailed information terminal node including Kaplan-Meier estimates, risk tables, survival summaries. show_importance Calculate display variable importance measures based improvement prediction accuracy. plot_tree Generate tree structure plot nodes, splits, survival curves. plot_survival Plot Kaplan-Meier survival curves terminal node confidence intervals risk tables. plot_importance Generate variable importance plot showing relative importance predictors tree construction. mtry Number variables randomly selected split. Leave empty use variables. Setting creates random forest-like approach. replace Use bootstrap sampling replacement tree construction. Creates robust trees may reduce interpretability. subset Fraction observations use tree construction. Leave empty use observations. Useful large datasets.

text: Comprehensive network analysis correlation structures using multiple algorithms including  Gaussian Graphical Models (GGM), LASSO regularized networks, partial correlations.  Provides network metrics, community detection, interactive visualizations, network  comparison tests. Suitable understanding complex relationships variables network topology.

title: Correlation Network Analysis ‚Äî correlationnetwork
code: correlationnetwork(   data,   vars,   group = NULL,   networkMethod = "correlation",   correlationMethod = "pearson",   threshold = 0.1,   significanceThreshold = 0.05,   onlySignificant = FALSE,   centralityMeasures = TRUE,   communityDetection = TRUE,   communityMethod = "walktrap",   networkComparison = FALSE,   plots = TRUE,   layoutAlgorithm = "spring",   nodeSize = "degree",   edgeWidth = "weight",   colorNodes = TRUE,   interactive = FALSE,   report = TRUE )

title: Correlation Network Analysis ‚Äî correlationnetwork
text: data data data frame. vars vector strings naming variables include network analysis. group Variable split analysis network comparison. networkMethod Method constructing network: 'correlation' (default), 'partial', 'ggm', 'lasso'. correlationMethod correlation method use: 'pearson' (default), 'spearman', 'kendall'. threshold Minimum absolute correlation value include edge network (default: 0.1). significanceThreshold Alpha level edge significance testing (default: 0.05). onlySignificant FALSE (default) TRUE, show statistically significant edges. centralityMeasures TRUE (default) FALSE, calculate node centrality measures. communityDetection TRUE (default) FALSE, perform community detection analysis. communityMethod Method community detection: 'walktrap' (default), 'louvain', 'leiden', 'spinglass', 'betweenness'. networkComparison FALSE (default) TRUE, perform network comparison tests grouping variable provided. plots TRUE (default) FALSE, generate network visualization plots. layoutAlgorithm Layout algorithm network visualization: 'spring' (default), 'circle', 'nicely', 'kk', 'lgl'. nodeSize Method sizing nodes: 'constant', 'degree' (default), 'betweenness', 'closeness', 'eigenvector'. edgeWidth Method edge width: 'weight' (default) 'constant'. colorNodes TRUE (default) FALSE, color nodes detected communities. interactive FALSE (default) TRUE, generate interactive network plots. report TRUE (default) FALSE, provide natural language interpretation network analysis.

title: Cost-Effectiveness Analysis ‚Äî costeffectiveness
code: costeffectiveness(   data,   strategy,   comparator_level,   cost,   effectiveness,   effectiveness_type = "binary",   effectiveness_label = "Correct Diagnoses",   calculate_icer = TRUE,   calculate_incremental = TRUE,   dominance_analysis = FALSE,   net_monetary_benefit = FALSE,   wtp_threshold = 50000,   multiple_wtp_thresholds = FALSE,   wtp_range = "0, 25000, 50000, 100000, 150000",   confidence_intervals = FALSE,   ci_method = "bootstrap",   bootstrap_samples = 1000,   confidence_level = 0.95,   deterministic_sensitivity = FALSE,   sensitivity_parameters =     "test_cost, follow_up_cost, test_sensitivity, test_specificity",   sensitivity_range_pct = 20,   probabilistic_sensitivity = FALSE,   psa_simulations = 1000,   cost_distribution = "gamma",   effect_distribution = "normal",   voi_analysis = FALSE,   evpi_population = 10000,   evppi_parameters = FALSE,   evppi_focus = "both",   subgroup_analysis = FALSE,   subgroup_variable,   time_horizon = 1,   discount_costs = FALSE,   discount_rate_costs = 3,   discount_effects = FALSE,   discount_rate_effects = 3,   plot_ce_plane = TRUE,   plot_ce_acceptability = FALSE,   plot_nmb = FALSE,   plot_tornado = FALSE,   plot_incremental_frontier = FALSE,   perspective = "healthcare",   include_indirect_costs = FALSE,   currency = "USD",   cost_year = 2024,   handling_missing = "complete",   random_seed = 12345 )

title: Cost-Effectiveness Analysis ‚Äî costeffectiveness
text: data data data frame. strategy Variable indicating diagnostic strategy used observation. least 2 levels (e.g., "New Test" vs. "Standard Care"). comparator_level level strategy variable represents comparator (baseline/reference) strategy others compared. cost Total cost per patient diagnostic strategy. include relevant costs: test costs, follow-procedures, treatment costs, adverse events. Express consistent currency units (e.g., USD, EUR). effectiveness Effectiveness measure per patient. Can correct diagnoses (0/1), QALYs, life-years gained, cancers detected, etc. Higher values represent better outcomes. effectiveness_type Type effectiveness measure analyzed. Affects interpretation labeling ICER results. effectiveness_label Custom label effectiveness measure (e.g., "Cancers Detected", "True Positives", "QALYs"). calculate_icer Calculate Incremental Cost-Effectiveness Ratio. ICER = (Cost_new - Cost_comparator) / (Effect_new - Effect_comparator). Represents additional cost per additional unit effectiveness. calculate_incremental Display incremental costs effects relative comparator strategy. dominance_analysis Identify dominated strategies (costly less effective) extended dominance (strategies inefficient frontier). net_monetary_benefit Calculate Net Monetary Benefit (NMB) specified willingness--pay thresholds. NMB = (Effectiveness √ó WTP) - Cost. Positive NMB indicates cost-effective threshold. wtp_threshold Willingness--pay threshold primary analysis (e.g., $50,000 per QALY US, ¬£20,000-30,000 per QALY UK). Used net benefit calculation. multiple_wtp_thresholds Evaluate cost-effectiveness multiple willingness--pay thresholds show robustness conclusions. wtp_range Comma-separated list willingness--pay thresholds analysis. Example: "0, 20000, 30000, 50000, 100000". confidence_intervals Calculate confidence intervals mean costs, mean effects, ICER using bootstrap parametric methods. ci_method Method confidence interval estimation. Bootstrap recommended cost data (often skewed). BCa (Bias-Corrected Accelerated) provides better coverage skewed distributions. bootstrap_samples Number bootstrap resamples confidence interval estimation. confidence_level Confidence level interval estimation. deterministic_sensitivity One-way sensitivity analysis varying individual parameters assess impact ICER. Creates tornado diagram showing influential parameters. sensitivity_parameters Comma-separated list parameter names deterministic sensitivity analysis. column names data. sensitivity_range_pct Percentage variation around base case sensitivity analysis. example, 20\ 120\ probabilistic_sensitivityMonte Carlo simulation propagate uncertainty parameters simultaneously. Generates cost-effectiveness acceptability curve (CEAC) showing probability cost-effectiveness different WTP thresholds. psa_simulationsNumber Monte Carlo simulations probabilistic sensitivity analysis. cost_distributionProbability distribution cost parameter uncertainty. Gamma recommended costs (non-negative, often right-skewed). effect_distributionProbability distribution effectiveness parameter uncertainty. Beta recommended proportions, normal continuous measures. voi_analysisCalculate Expected Value Perfect Information (EVPI) quantify expected cost uncertainty decision. EVPI represents maximum value conducting research eliminate parameter uncertainty. evpi_populationPopulation size affected decision relevant time horizon. EVPI calculated per-person multiplied population give total value eliminating uncertainty. evppi_parametersCalculate Expected Value Perfect Parameter Information (EVPPI) specific parameters. Shows parameters contribute decision uncertainty. evppi_focusWhich parameters include EVPPI calculation. Useful identifying whether cost effectiveness uncertainty drives decision uncertainty. subgroup_analysisPerform cost-effectiveness analysis stratified subgroups identify populations new strategy cost-effective. subgroup_variableVariable defining subgroups stratified analysis (e.g., disease stage, age group, risk category). time_horizonTime horizon cost-effectiveness analysis years. Short-term diagnostic tests (1 year), longer treatments affecting survival. discount_costsApply discounting future costs (relevant multi-year time horizons). discount_rate_costsAnnual discount rate future costs (typically 3-5\discount_effectsApply discounting future health effects (QALYs, life-years).discount_rate_effectsAnnual discount rate future effects (often cost discount rate).plot_ce_planeScatter plot showing incremental costs (y-axis) vs. incremental effects (x-axis). Quadrants indicate dominance relationships. Willingness--pay threshold shown diagonal line.plot_ce_acceptabilityCEAC showing probability strategy cost-effective across range willingness--pay thresholds. Requires probabilistic sensitivity analysis.plot_nmbBar plot showing net monetary benefit strategy specified WTP threshold. Strategy highest NMB optimal.plot_tornadoTornado diagram showing one-way sensitivity analysis results. Parameters ordered impact ICER, showing range ICER values across parameter uncertainty ranges.plot_incremental_frontierPlot showing efficient frontier connecting non-dominated strategies.perspectivePerspective cost-effectiveness analysis determines costs included. Healthcare system includes direct medical costs, societal includes productivity losses patient time costs.include_indirect_costsInclude indirect costs (productivity losses, patient time) societal perspective.currencyCurrency cost reporting (e.g., USD, EUR, GBP, JPY).cost_yearReference year cost values (inflation adjustment needed).handling_missingMethod handling missing cost effectiveness data.random_seedRandom seed bootstrap Monte Carlo simulations.   results object containing:

title: Co-Testing Analysis ‚Äî cotest
text: Function analyzing combined results two concurrent diagnostic tests. Calculates post-test probabilities based various scenarios (either test positive, positive, negative).

title: Co-Testing Analysis ‚Äî cotest
code: cotest(   test1_sens = 0.8,   test1_spec = 0.9,   test2_sens = 0.75,   test2_spec = 0.95,   indep = FALSE,   cond_dep_pos = 0.05,   cond_dep_neg = 0.05,   prevalence = 0.1,   fnote = FALSE,   fagan = FALSE,   preset = "custom" )

title: Co-Testing Analysis ‚Äî cotest
text: test1_sens Sensitivity (true positive rate) Test 1. test1_spec Specificity (true negative rate) Test 1. test2_sens Sensitivity (true positive rate) Test 2. test2_spec Specificity (true negative rate) Test 2. indep Assume tests conditionally independent (default false safety). Use true tests measure completely different phenomena. cond_dep_pos Conditional dependence tests subjects disease. Value 0 (independence) 1 (complete dependence). cond_dep_neg Conditional dependence tests subjects without disease. Value 0 (independence) 1 (complete dependence). prevalence Prior probability (disease prevalence population). #> #> Understanding Test Dependence in Diagnostic Testing #> #> What is conditional independence vs. dependence? #> #> Two diagnostic tests are conditionally independent if the result of #> one test does not influence the result of the other test, *given the #> disease status*. In other words, within the diseased population, the #> probability of Test 1 being positive is not affected by knowing the #> result of Test 2, and vice versa. The same applies within the #> non-diseased population. #> #> Tests are conditionally dependent when the result of one test affects #> the probability of the other test result, even when we know the #> patient's true disease status. #> #> Mathematical Formulation #> #> Independent Tests: When tests are independent, joint probabilities are #> simply the product of individual probabilities: #> #> P(Test1+ and Test2+ | Disease+) = P(Test1+ | Disease+) √ó P(Test2+ | #> Disease+) = Sens‚ÇÅ √ó Sens‚ÇÇ #> P(Test1+ and Test2+ | Disease‚àí) = P(Test1+ | Disease‚àí) √ó P(Test2+ | #> Disease‚àí) = (1‚àíSpec‚ÇÅ) √ó (1‚àíSpec‚ÇÇ) #> P(Test1‚àí and Test2‚àí | Disease+) = P(Test1‚àí | Disease+) √ó P(Test2‚àí | #> Disease+) = (1‚àíSens‚ÇÅ) √ó (1‚àíSens‚ÇÇ) #> P(Test1‚àí and Test2‚àí | Disease‚àí) = P(Test1‚àí | Disease‚àí) √ó P(Test2‚àí | #> Disease‚àí) = Spec‚ÇÅ √ó Spec‚ÇÇ #> #> Dependent Tests: When tests are dependent, we adjust these #> probabilities using a correlation parameter (denoted as œÅ or œà) that #> ranges from -1 (inverse correlation) to 1 (maximum possible #> dependence): #> #> P(Test1+ and Test2+ | Disease+) = (Sens‚ÇÅ √ó Sens‚ÇÇ) + œÅ·µ®‚Çí‚Çõ √ó ‚àö(Sens‚ÇÅ √ó #> (1‚àíSens‚ÇÅ) √ó Sens‚ÇÇ √ó (1‚àíSens‚ÇÇ)) #> P(Test1+ and Test2+ | Disease‚àí) = ((1‚àíSpec‚ÇÅ) √ó (1‚àíSpec‚ÇÇ)) + œÅ‚Çô‚Çëùëî √ó #> ‚àö((1‚àíSpec‚ÇÅ) √ó Spec‚ÇÅ √ó (1‚àíSpec‚ÇÇ) √ó Spec‚ÇÇ) #> #> Extreme values are automatically truncated to stay within feasible #> joint bounds; the realized correlation after truncation is reported. #> #> Note: Similar adjustments are made for the other joint probabilities. #> #> When to Use Dependent vs. Independent Models #> #> Use the independence model when: #> #> Tests measure completely different biological phenomena #> Tests use different biological specimens or mechanisms #> You have no evidence of correlation between test results #> You have limited information about how the tests interact #> #> Use the dependence model when: #> #> Tests measure the same or similar biological phenomena #> Tests are based on the same biological specimen or mechanism #> Previous studies indicate correlation between test results #> Both tests are affected by the same confounding factors #> You have observed that knowing one test result predicts the other #> #> Real-World Examples of Dependent Tests #> #> Two imaging tests (e.g., MRI and CT) looking at the same anatomical #> structure #> Two serological tests that detect different antibodies but against the #> same pathogen #> Tests that may both be affected by the same confounding factor (e.g., #> inflammation) #> Multiple readings of the same test by different observers #> Two different molecular tests detecting different genes of the same #> pathogen #> #> Estimating Dependency Parameters #> #> The conditional dependence parameters (œÅ·µ®‚Çí‚Çõ for diseased subjects and #> œÅ‚Çô‚Çëùëî for non-diseased subjects) ideally should be estimated from #> paired testing data with known disease status. Values typically range #> from 0 to 0.5 in practice, with higher values indicating stronger #> dependence. When no data is available, sensitivity analyses using a #> range of plausible values (e.g., 0.05, 0.1, 0.2) can reveal how much #> dependence affects results. #> #> Impact of Ignoring Dependence #> #> Ignoring conditional dependence when it exists tends to: #> #> Overestimate the benefit of combined testing #> Exaggerate post-test probabilities (either too high for positive #> results or too low for negative results) #> Produce unrealistically narrow confidence intervals #> Lead to overly optimistic assessment of diagnostic accuracy #> #> Clinical Interpretation: #> #> Disease prevalence (pre-test probability): 10.0% #> #> Both tests positive: 93.0% probability (9.3x increase) - strong #> evidence for disease #> #> Both tests negative: 0.6% probability (0.06x change) (major decrease) #> #> Single positive test: #> #> #> Test 1 positive only: 19.0% (moderate increase) #> Test 2 positive only: 27.0% (moderate increase) #> #>
#> #> #> Copy-ready summary: #> #>

0.8184 #> #>
#> #> Understanding Test Dependence in Diagnostic Testing #> #> What is conditional independence vs. dependence? #> #> Two diagnostic tests are conditionally independent if the result of #> one test does not influence the result of the other test, *given the #> disease status*. In other words, within the diseased population, the #> probability of Test 1 being positive is not affected by knowing the #> result of Test 2, and vice versa. The same applies within the #> non-diseased population. #> #> Tests are conditionally dependent when the result of one test affects #> the probability of the other test result, even when we know the #> patient's true disease status. #> #> Mathematical Formulation #> #> Independent Tests: When tests are independent, joint probabilities are #> simply the product of individual probabilities: #> #> P(Test1+ and Test2+ | Disease+) = P(Test1+ | Disease+) √ó P(Test2+ | #> Disease+) = Sens‚ÇÅ √ó Sens‚ÇÇ #> P(Test1+ and Test2+ | Disease‚àí) = P(Test1+ | Disease‚àí) √ó P(Test2+ | #> Disease‚àí) = (1‚àíSpec‚ÇÅ) √ó (1‚àíSpec‚ÇÇ) #> P(Test1‚àí and Test2‚àí | Disease+) = P(Test1‚àí | Disease+) √ó P(Test2‚àí | #> Disease+) = (1‚àíSens‚ÇÅ) √ó (1‚àíSens‚ÇÇ) #> P(Test1‚àí and Test2‚àí | Disease‚àí) = P(Test1‚àí | Disease‚àí) √ó P(Test2‚àí | #> Disease‚àí) = Spec‚ÇÅ √ó Spec‚ÇÇ #> #> Dependent Tests: When tests are dependent, we adjust these #> probabilities using a correlation parameter (denoted as œÅ or œà) that #> ranges from -1 (inverse correlation) to 1 (maximum possible #> dependence): #> #> P(Test1+ and Test2+ | Disease+) = (Sens‚ÇÅ √ó Sens‚ÇÇ) + œÅ·µ®‚Çí‚Çõ √ó ‚àö(Sens‚ÇÅ √ó #> (1‚àíSens‚ÇÅ) √ó Sens‚ÇÇ √ó (1‚àíSens‚ÇÇ)) #> P(Test1+ and Test2+ | Disease‚àí) = ((1‚àíSpec‚ÇÅ) √ó (1‚àíSpec‚ÇÇ)) + œÅ‚Çô‚Çëùëî √ó #> ‚àö((1‚àíSpec‚ÇÅ) √ó Spec‚ÇÅ √ó (1‚àíSpec‚ÇÇ) √ó Spec‚ÇÇ) #> #> Extreme values are automatically truncated to stay within feasible #> joint bounds; the realized correlation after truncation is reported. #> #> Note: Similar adjustments are made for the other joint probabilities. #> #> When to Use Dependent vs. Independent Models #> #> Use the independence model when: #> #> Tests measure completely different biological phenomena #> Tests use different biological specimens or mechanisms #> You have no evidence of correlation between test results #> You have limited information about how the tests interact #> #> Use the dependence model when: #> #> Tests measure the same or similar biological phenomena #> Tests are based on the same biological specimen or mechanism #> Previous studies indicate correlation between test results #> Both tests are affected by the same confounding factors #> You have observed that knowing one test result predicts the other #> #> Real-World Examples of Dependent Tests #> #> Two imaging tests (e.g., MRI and CT) looking at the same anatomical #> structure #> Two serological tests that detect different antibodies but against the #> same pathogen #> Tests that may both be affected by the same confounding factor (e.g., #> inflammation) #> Multiple readings of the same test by different observers #> Two different molecular tests detecting different genes of the same #> pathogen #> #> Estimating Dependency Parameters #> #> The conditional dependence parameters (œÅ·µ®‚Çí‚Çõ for diseased subjects and #> œÅ‚Çô‚Çëùëî for non-diseased subjects) ideally should be estimated from #> paired testing data with known disease status. Values typically range #> from 0 to 0.5 in practice, with higher values indicating stronger #> dependence. When no data is available, sensitivity analyses using a #> range of plausible values (e.g., 0.05, 0.1, 0.2) can reveal how much #> dependence affects results. #> #> Impact of Ignoring Dependence #> #> Ignoring conditional dependence when it exists tends to: #> #> Overestimate the benefit of combined testing #> Exaggerate post-test probabilities (either too high for positive #> results or too low for negative results) #> Produce unrealistically narrow confidence intervals #> Lead to overly optimistic assessment of diagnostic accuracy #> #> Clinical Interpretation: #> #> Disease prevalence (pre-test probability): 5.0% #> #> Both tests positive: 67.2% probability (13.4x increase) - strong #> evidence for disease #> #> Both tests negative: 0.3% probability (0.06x change) (major decrease) #> #> Single positive test: #> #> #> Test 1 positive only: 6.4% (slight increase) #> Test 2 positive only: 8.0% (moderate increase) #> #>
#> #> #> Copy-ready summary: #> #>

Co-testing with #> Test 1 (sensitivity 85%, specificity 88%) and Test 2 (sensitivity 82%, #> specificity 92%) in a population with 5.0% disease prevalence showed: #> when both tests are positive, disease probability is 67.2% (13.4x #> increase); when both are negative, disease probability is 0.3% (0.06x #> decrease). #> #> # High-stakes screening scenario cotest( test1_sens = 0.95, test1_spec = 0.85, test2_sens = 0.90, test2_spec = 0.90, prevalence = 0.02, indep = TRUE, fagan = TRUE, fnote = TRUE ) #> #> CO-TESTING ANALYSIS #> #>

#> #> Welcome to Co-Testing Analysis #> #> Purpose: This analysis evaluates the combined diagnostic performance #> of two tests when used together, accounting for potential dependence #> between tests. #> #> Quick Start Guide #> #> Choose a Clinical Preset (optional): Select from evidence-based #> scenarios like HPV+Pap, PSA+DRE, Troponin+ECG, etc. to auto-populate #> all parameters with published values. #> Enter Custom Test Parameters: Input sensitivity and specificity for #> each test, or use preset values. #> Set Disease Prevalence: Enter the pre-test probability of disease in #> your population. #> Configure Test Independence: Specify whether tests are conditionally #> independent or dependent (see "Understanding Test Dependence" section #> for guidance). #> Review Results: The analysis provides post-test probabilities for all #> test combination outcomes, including the critical *Either Test #> Positive (Parallel Rule)* used in clinical co-testing algorithms. #> #> Key Clinical Scenarios #> #> Either Test Positive (Parallel Rule): At least one test is positive ‚Üí #> rule in disease (high sensitivity strategy) #> Both Tests Positive: Maximum certainty for disease presence (high #> specificity strategy) #> Both Tests Negative: Strong evidence against disease (rule out #> strategy) #> Single Positive: Only one test positive ‚Üí intermediate probability #> requiring clinical judgment #> #> Preset Scenarios Include #> #> HPV + Pap Smear: Cervical cancer screening (dependent tests) #> PSA + DRE: Prostate cancer screening (dependent tests) #> Troponin + ECG: Acute coronary syndrome (independent tests) #> Mammogram + Ultrasound: Breast cancer screening (dependent tests) #> COVID Antigen + PCR: SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis (independent tests) #> Chest X-ray + Sputum Culture: Tuberculosis diagnosis (dependent tests) #> #> Data provenance: Preset values are literature-informed exemplars; title: Cox Proportional Hazards Model Diagnostics ‚Äî coxdiagnosticsClass
text: module implements diagnostic capabilities requested GitHub Issue #61, providing comprehensive model validation Cox regression analysis. diagnostic plots help identify model violations, influential observations, assess overall model fit quality essential clinical research applications. Key diagnostic plot types: Martingale residuals: Detect non-linear relationships outliers Deviance residuals: Identify poorly fitted observations Score residuals: Assess influential observations Schoenfeld residuals: Test proportional hazards assumption DFBeta plots: Evaluate influence individual observations

Provide Olson identifier "Europe/Istanbul", "America/New_York", "UTC", "system" use local machine timezone. Excel serial Unix epoch conversions always use UTC regardless setting. preview_rows Number rows display preview tables. Shows original values, corrected datetimes, extracted components quality checking. extract_year Extract display year component preview table. extract_month Extract display month component preview table. extract_monthname Extract display month name preview table. extract_day Extract display day component preview table. extract_hour Extract display hour component preview table. extract_minute Extract display minute component preview table. extract_second Extract display second component preview table. extract_dayname Extract display day name preview table. extract_weeknum Extract display week number preview table. extract_quarter Extract display quarter preview table. extract_dayofyear Extract display day year preview table. show_quality_metrics Display comprehensive quality metrics including parsing success rate, invalid dates, data quality warnings. show_summary Generate plain-language summary suitable copying reports clinical documentation. show_explanations Display educational content explaining function , use , interpret results. show_glossary Display definitions datetime-related terms (Excel serial dates, Unix epoch, timezones, etc.) aid interpretation.

title: Date/DateTime Validator ‚Äî datevalidator
text: data data data frame. date_vars Variables containing date datetime information various formats need validation quality assessment. Can handle character strings, numeric values, factors date/datetime representations. correction_method Method date/datetime validation. datefixR provides robust format detection, anytime offers flexible parsing, lubridate allows format specification, consensus combines methods maximum reliability. date_format Expected date datetime format ambiguous cases. Auto-detect tries determine likely format based data patterns. HMS formats include time components (hours, minutes, seconds). day_impute Day month impute day missing (1-31). Default 1st month. value exceeds days month, last day month used. month_impute Month impute month missing (1-12). Default 7 (July). Commonly used middle-year value clinical research. handle_excel Whether convert Excel numeric date values (days since 1900-01-01). Useful data exported Excel spreadsheets. timezone Timezone output dates/datetimes. Use UTC standardization, local timezone time--day information critical. applies anytime consensus methods. show_correction_table Display detailed table showing original values, validated values, validation status observation. show_quality_assessment Provide quality assessment including success rates, common problems, recommendations validation. show_format_analysis Analyze detected date/datetime formats patterns original data. show_correction_summary Summary statistics validation process including /comparison data quality metrics. show_interpretation Display guidance date/datetime validation methods, best practices, recommendations clinical research data. Includes information DateTime Converter module.

text: Data frames variables gold standard reference test results: patient_id Patient identifier GoldStandard/Reference True disease status (gold standard) NewTest/Test Test result evaluated Additional clinical variables Age, symptoms, risk factors, etc. decision_test: Basic diagnostic test evaluation (n=200, 30% prevalence) patient_id Patient identifier GoldStandard True disease status (Negative/Positive) NewTest Test result (Negative/Positive, Sens=0.85, Spec=0.90) age Patient age years sex Patient sex (Female/Male) decision_screening: Cancer screening test low prevalence (n=250, 5% prevalence) patient_id Patient identifier Biopsy Gold standard biopsy result (Benign/Malignant) ScreeningTest Screening test result (Negative/Positive, Sens=0.92, Spec=0.88) age Patient age years risk_factor Cancer risk factor (Low/Medium/High) decision_diagnostic: Clinical diagnostic test high prevalence (n=180, 60% prevalence) patient_id Patient identifier GoldStandard True disease status (Absent/Present) ClinicalTest Clinical test result (Negative/Positive, Sens=0.88, Spec=0.85) symptom_severity Symptom severity score (1-10) duration_days Symptom duration days decision_biomarker: Cardiac biomarker test evaluation (n=220, 35% prevalence) patient_id Patient identifier Angiography Gold standard angiography (No_MI/MI) Troponin Troponin test result (Normal/Elevated, Sens=0.95, Spec=0.92) chest_pain Chest pain severity (None/Mild/Severe) ecg_changes ECG findings (Normal/Abnormal) decision_imaging: Medical imaging test performance (n=160, 40% prevalence) patient_id Patient identifier Pathology Pathology diagnosis (Benign/Malignant) CT_Scan CT scan result (Normal/Abnormal, Sens=0.87, Spec=0.83) tumor_size_cm Tumor size centimeters location Tumor location (Lung/Liver/Kidney/Pancreas) decision_infectious: Infectious disease rapid test (n=200, 25% prevalence) patient_id Patient identifier Culture Gold standard culture result (Negative/Positive) RapidTest Rapid test result (Negative/Positive, Sens=0.82, Spec=0.95) fever Fever present (/Yes) symptom_onset_days Days since symptom onset decision_small: Small sample dataset (n=30, 40% prevalence) patient_id Patient identifier GoldStandard True disease status (Negative/Positive) NewTest Test result (Negative/Positive, Sens=0.85, Spec=0.85) decision_large: Large sample dataset (n=500, 30% prevalence) patient_id Patient identifier GoldStandard True disease status (Negative/Positive) NewTest Test result (Negative/Positive, Sens=0.88, Spec=0.90) age Patient age years comorbidities Number comorbidities decision_perfect: Perfect test performance (n=150, 35% prevalence) patient_id Patient identifier GoldStandard True disease status (Negative/Positive) PerfectTest Perfect test result (Sens=1.00, Spec=1.00) age Patient age years decision_poor: Poor test performance (n=140, 30% prevalence) patient_id Patient identifier GoldStandard True disease status (Negative/Positive) PoorTest Poor performing test (Sens=0.60, Spec=0.65) decision_rare: Rare disease scenario (n=300, 2% prevalence) patient_id Patient identifier GoldStandard True disease status (Negative/Positive) NewTest Test result (Negative/Positive, Sens=0.90, Spec=0.95) genetic_marker Genetic marker status (Absent/Present) decision_common: Common disease scenario (n=180, 75% prevalence) patient_id Patient identifier GoldStandard True disease status (Negative/Positive) NewTest Test result (Negative/Positive, Sens=0.85, Spec=0.88) decision_missing: Dataset missing values (n=150, ~5% missing) patient_id Patient identifier GoldStandard True disease status missing values NewTest Test result missing values age Patient age years decision_multilevel: Three-level variables indeterminate results (n=180) patient_id Patient identifier GoldStandard True disease status (Negative/Positive) NewTest Test result (Negative/Positive/Indeterminate, ~10% indeterminate) decision_pathology: Pathology frozen section evaluation (n=190, 45% prevalence) patient_id Patient identifier Biopsy Permanent section diagnosis (Benign/Malignant) FrozenSection Frozen section diagnosis (Benign/Malignant, Sens=0.93, Spec=0.96) specimen_type Specimen type (Core_Biopsy/Excision/FNA) tumor_grade Tumor grade (Low/Intermediate/High) decision_pointofcare: Point--care test evaluation (n=210, 28% prevalence) patient_id Patient identifier LabTest Laboratory test result (Negative/Positive) PointOfCare Point--care test result (Negative/Positive, Sens=0.78, Spec=0.92) setting Testing setting (Emergency/Clinic/Home) urgency Clinical urgency (Routine/Urgent/Critical)

title: Compare Medical Decision Tests ‚Äî decisioncompare
text: Function comparing multiple Medical Decision Tests. Compares sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, negative predictive value, metrics different tests golden standard. Includes statistical comparison using McNemar's test confidence intervals differences.

title: Compare Medical Decision Tests ‚Äî decisioncompare
code: decisioncompare(   data,   gold,   goldPositive,   test1,   test1Positive,   test2,   test2Positive,   test3 = NULL,   test3Positive,   pp = FALSE,   pprob = 0.3,   od = FALSE,   fnote = FALSE,   ci = FALSE,   plot = FALSE,   excludeIndeterminate = FALSE,   radarplot = FALSE,   statComp = FALSE,   showSummary = FALSE,   showExplanations = FALSE,   showReportSentence = FALSE )

title: Compare Medical Decision Tests ‚Äî decisioncompare
text: data data data frame. gold gold standard reference variable representing true disease status. goldPositive level indicating presence disease gold standard variable. test1 first diagnostic test variable evaluated performance. test1Positive level representing positive result Test 1. test2 second diagnostic test variable comparison analysis. test2Positive level representing positive result Test 2. test3 Optional third diagnostic test variable extended comparison analysis. test3Positive level representing positive result Test 3. pp Enable custom prior probability (prevalence) predictive value calculations. pprob Prior probability (disease prevalence community). Requires value 0.001 0.999, default 0.300. od Boolean selection whether show frequency tables. Default 'false'. fnote . ci . plot Generate comparison plot showing test performance metrics. excludeIndeterminate TRUE, drop rows test/gold values neither specified positive level clear negative level avoid inflating specificity/NPV equivocal results. radarplot Generate radar plot comprehensive test comparison visualization. statComp Perform statistical comparison tests (McNemar's test confidence intervals differences). showSummary Boolean show natural language summary statistical comparisons. showExplanations Boolean show explanations, glossary, educational content. showReportSentence Boolean show manuscript-ready report sentence.

title: Compare Medical Decision Tests ‚Äî decisioncompare
code: # Basic comparison of two diagnostic tests library(ClinicoPath) data('histopathology')  # Example 1: Compare imaging vs blood test performance result1 <- decisioncompare(     data = histopathology,     gold = "Golden Standart",     goldPositive = "1",     test1 = "New Test",     test1Positive = "1",     test2 = "Rater 1",     test2Positive = "1",     ci = TRUE,     plot = TRUE ) #> Error in decisioncompare(data = histopathology, gold = "Golden Standart",     goldPositive = "1", test1 = "New Test", test1Positive = "1",     test2 = "Rater 1", test2Positive = "1", ci = TRUE, plot = TRUE): argument "test3Positive" is missing, with no default  # Example 2: Three-test comparison with statistical analysis result2 <- decisioncompare(     data = histopathology,     gold = "Golden Standart",     goldPositive = "1",     test1 = "New Test",     test1Positive = "1",     test2 = "Rater 1",     test2Positive = "1",     test3 = "Rater 2",     test3Positive = "1",     statComp = TRUE,     radarplot = TRUE ) #> Performing 3 pairwise comparisons with Holm-Bonferroni correction... #> Statistical comparisons completed (3 comparisons, Holm-Bonferroni corrected).  # Example 3: Using custom prevalence for clinical setting result3 <- decisioncompare(     data = histopathology,     gold = "Golden Standart",     goldPositive = "1",     test1 = "New Test",     test1Positive = "1",     test2 = "Rater 1",     test2Positive = "1",     pp = TRUE,     pprob = 0.15,  # 15\% prevalence in screening population     od = TRUE      # Show original frequency tables ) #> Error in decisioncompare(data = histopathology, gold = "Golden Standart",     goldPositive = "1", test1 = "New Test", test1Positive = "1",     test2 = "Rater 1", test2Positive = "1", pp = TRUE, pprob = 0.15,     od = TRUE): argument "test3Positive" is missing, with no default

üìù Report Sentences #> #>

Methods #> Section: #> #>

We compared the #> diagnostic performance of 3 tests (CT_Scan, MRI, Biomarker) against #> the gold standard reference using diagnostic accuracy analysis. The #> study included 220 cases with complete data. Performance metrics #> calculated included sensitivity, specificity, positive and negative #> predictive values, likelihood ratios, and overall accuracy. #> #>

Results #> Section: #> #>

Among the tests #> evaluated, MRI demonstrated optimal diagnostic performance with 92.6% #> sensitivity (95% CI: [see confidence interval table]), 90.1% #> specificity (95% CI: [see confidence interval table]), 80.8% positive #> predictive value, 96.5% negative predictive value, and 90.9% overall #> accuracy. The likelihood ratio for positive results was 9.39 and for #> negative results was 0.08. #> #>

This tool compares the #> diagnostic performance of multiple medical tests against a gold #> standard reference. It systematically evaluates sensitivity, #> specificity, predictive values, likelihood ratios, and overall #> accuracy to help you determine which test performs best for your #> clinical scenario. #> #>

    Test Validation: #> Comparing new diagnostic methods against established standardsMethod #> Comparison: Evaluating which of several tests performs betterClinical #> Research: Validating biomarkers, imaging techniques, or clinical #> assessmentsQuality Assessment: Measuring agreement between different #> raters or methodsProtocol Development: Optimizing diagnostic #> workflows

    style="color: #e65100; margin-top: 0;">üìù How to Use This Analysis #> #>

      style="background-color: #f3e5f5; border: 1px solid #9c27b0; padding: #> 20px; border-radius: 8px; margin: 20px 0;">

      üìà Key Metrics Explained #> #>
      #> #> Sensitivity: Probability test is positive when disease present #> (rule-out ability) #> #> Specificity: Probability test is negative when disease absent (rule-in #> ability) #> #> PPV: Probability of disease when test positive #> #> NPV: Probability of no disease when test negative #> #> LR+: How much positive test increases odds of disease #> #> LR-: How much negative test decreases odds of disease #> #> Accuracy: Overall probability of correct classification #> #> McNemar Test: Statistical comparison between paired tests #> #>

      ‚öïÔ∏è Clinical Interpretation Guidelines #> #>

      Screening Tests #> (Rule-Out): #> #>

      ‚Ä¢ Sensitivity ‚â•95%: Excellent #> ‚Ä¢ NPV ‚â•95%: High confidence #> ‚Ä¢ Goal: Minimize false negatives #> #>

      Confirmatory Tests (Rule-In): #> #>

      ‚Ä¢ Specificity ‚â•95%: Excellent #> ‚Ä¢ PPV ‚â•90%: High confidence #> ‚Ä¢ Goal: Minimize false positives #> #>

      ‚ö†Ô∏è Important Assumptions & Limitations #> #>
        Gold Standard: Assumes #> your reference test is truly accurateSample Size: Results more #> reliable with larger, representative samplesPrevalence Dependency: PPV #> and NPV vary with disease prevalenceMcNemar Test: Requires #> paired/matched data for statistical comparisonsMissing Data: Cases #> with incomplete data are excluded from analysisConfidence Intervals: #> Calculated using Wilson method for better accuracy #> #>

      üìà Key Metrics Explained #> #>
      #> #> Sensitivity: Probability test is positive when disease present #> (rule-out ability) #> #> Specificity: Probability test is negative when disease absent (rule-in #> ability) #> #> PPV: Probability of disease when test positive #> #> NPV: Probability of no disease when test negative #> #> LR+: How much positive test increases odds of disease #> #> LR-: How much negative test decreases odds of disease #> #> Accuracy: Overall probability of correct classification #> #> McNemar Test: Statistical comparison between paired tests #> #>

Methods #> Section: #> #>

The study #> included 180 cases with complete data. Results #> Section: #> #>

Among the tests #> evaluated, Test3 demonstrated optimal diagnostic performance with 81% #> sensitivity (95% CI: [see confidence interval table]), 95.7% #> specificity (95% CI: [see confidence interval table]), 91.1% positive #> predictive value, 90.3% negative predictive value, and 90.6% overall #> accuracy. Consider local #> validation studies before implementation. #> #>

style="color: #1565c0; margin-top: 0;">üìä What This Analysis Does #> #>

This tool compares the #> diagnostic performance of multiple medical tests against a gold #> standard reference. It systematically evaluates sensitivity, #> specificity, predictive values, likelihood ratios, and overall #> accuracy to help you determine which test performs best for your #> clinical scenario. #> #>

üéØ When to Use This Analysis #> #>
    Test Validation: #> Comparing new diagnostic methods against established standardsMethod #> Comparison: Evaluating which of several tests performs betterClinical #> Research: Validating biomarkers, imaging techniques, or clinical #> assessmentsQuality Assessment: Measuring agreement between different #> raters or methodsProtocol Development: Optimizing diagnostic #> workflows

    style="color: #e65100; margin-top: 0;">üìù How to Use This Analysis #> #>
      Select Gold Standard: #> Choose your most reliable reference test (e.g., biopsy, expert #> consensus)Choose Tests to Compare: Select 2-3 diagnostic tests you #> want to evaluateDefine Positive Levels: Specify what constitutes a #> "positive" result for each testConfigure Options: Enable statistical #> comparisons, confidence intervals, or visualizations as neededRun #> Analysis: Review results tables and clinical interpretationsCopy #> Report: Use the auto-generated sentences for your documentation
      style="background-color: #f3e5f5; border: 1px solid #9c27b0; padding: #> 20px; border-radius: 8px; margin: 20px 0;">

      üìà Key Metrics Explained #> #>
      #> #> Sensitivity: Probability test is positive when disease present #> (rule-out ability) #> #> Specificity: Probability test is negative when disease absent (rule-in #> ability) #> #> PPV: Probability of disease when test positive #> #> NPV: Probability of no disease when test negative #> #> LR+: How much positive test increases odds of disease #> #> LR-: How much negative test decreases odds of disease #> #> Accuracy: Overall probability of correct classification #> #> McNemar Test: Statistical comparison between paired tests #> #>

      ‚öïÔ∏è Clinical Interpretation Guidelines #> #>

      Screening Tests #> (Rule-Out): #> #>

      ‚Ä¢ Sensitivity ‚â•95%: Excellent #> ‚Ä¢ NPV ‚â•95%: High confidence #> ‚Ä¢ Goal: Minimize false negatives #> #>

      Confirmatory Tests (Rule-In): #> #>

      ‚Ä¢ Specificity ‚â•95%: Excellent #> ‚Ä¢ PPV ‚â•90%: High confidence #> ‚Ä¢ Goal: Minimize false positives #> #>

      ‚ö†Ô∏è Important Assumptions & Limitations #> #>
        Gold Standard: Assumes #> your reference test is truly accurateSample Size: Results more #> reliable with larger, representative samplesPrevalence Dependency: PPV #> and NPV vary with disease prevalenceMcNemar Test: Requires #> paired/matched data for statistical comparisonsMissing Data: Cases #> with incomplete data are excluded from analysisConfidence Intervals: #> Calculated using Wilson method for better accuracy #> #>

title: Decision Curve Analysis ‚Äî decisioncurve
text: data data data frame. outcome Binary outcome variable (0/1 FALSE/TRUE). represents condition event want predict. outcomePositive level outcome variable represents positive case (presence condition/event). models Variables representing predicted probabilities risk scores different models. Can include multiple models comparison. modelNames Optional comma-separated list names models. provided, variable names used. thresholdRange Range threshold probabilities evaluate. thresholdMin Minimum threshold probability using custom range. thresholdMax Maximum threshold probability using custom range. thresholdStep Step size threshold probabilities. showTable Display table net benefit values selected thresholds. selectedThresholds Comma-separated list threshold probabilities display table. showPlot Display decision curve plot. plotStyle Style decision curve plot. showReferenceLinesLabels Show labels "Treat " "Treat None" reference lines. highlightRange Highlight clinically relevant threshold range plot. highlightMin Minimum threshold highlighted range. highlightMax Maximum threshold highlighted range. calculateClinicalImpact Calculate clinical impact metrics (number needed screen, etc.). populationSize Population size calculating clinical impact metrics. showInterventionAvoided Show many unnecessary interventions avoided compared treat-. confidenceIntervals Calculate bootstrap confidence intervals net benefit curves. bootReps Number bootstrap replications confidence intervals. ciLevel Confidence level bootstrap confidence intervals. showOptimalThreshold Identify display optimal threshold probabilities model. compareModels Calculate statistical tests comparing model performance. weightedAUC Calculate weighted area decision curve. clinicalDecisionRule Add clinical decision rule analysis comparison models. decisionRuleVar Binary variable indicating whether clinical rule recommends intervention (1/0 yes/). decisionRulePositive level rule variable indicates positive recommendation (treat/intervene). decisionRuleLabel Label clinical decision rule plots tables. showClinicalImpactPlot Display clinical impact plot showing number true positives false positives per population unit across threshold probabilities. showNetBenefitCI Display confidence intervals around net benefit curves decision curve plot. costBenefitAnalysis Perform cost-benefit analysis incorporating costs testing, treatment, outcomes. testCost Cost per test screening procedure (currency units). treatmentCost Cost treatment intervention (currency units). benefitCorrectTreatment Monetary benefit QALY-equivalent value correctly treating true positive. harmFalseTreatment Cost harm treating false positive (unnecessary treatment). showStandardizedNetBenefit Calculate display standardized net benefit (net benefit per 100 patients). multiModelComparison Perform comprehensive pairwise comparisons models statistical tests. comparisonMethod Statistical method comparing decision curves models. showDecisionConsequences Show detailed table decision consequences (TP, FP, TN, FN) selected thresholds. resourceUtilization Calculate resource utilization metrics (tests performed, treatments administered). showRelativeUtility Display relative utility curve comparing model default strategies.

text: data data data frame containing decision tree parameters. treeType Type decision tree create. clinicalPreset Pre-configured analysis templates common clinical decision analysis scenarios. decisions Variables representing decision nodes (treatment options). healthStates Variables defining health states Markov model. transitionProbs Variables containing transition probabilities health states. cycleLength Length Markov cycle years. probabilities Variables containing probability values chance nodes. costs Variables containing cost values terminal nodes. utilities Variables containing utility/effectiveness values. outcomes Variables representing clinical outcomes. layout Layout orientation decision tree. nodeShapes Use different shapes different node types. showProbabilities Display probability values tree branches. showCosts Display cost values terminal nodes. showUtilities Display utility/effectiveness values. calculateExpectedValues Calculate display expected costs utilities. calculateNMB Calculate net monetary benefit (NMB) decision paths using threshold analysis. willingnessToPay Willingness pay threshold (cost per QALY) NMB calculations. sensitivityAnalysis Perform one-way sensitivity analysis key parameters. discountRate Annual discount rate future costs benefits rate . separateDiscountRates Use separate discount rates costs utilities. discountRateCost Annual discount rate costs. discountRateUtility Annual discount rate utilities QALYs. timeHorizon Time horizon analysis years. nodeLabels Display descriptive labels nodes. branchLabels Display labels tree branches. colorScheme Color scheme decision tree visualization. summaryTable Show summary table expected values cost-effectiveness ratios. tornado Create tornado diagram sensitivity analysis. decisionComparison Show comparison table NMB scores decision paths. incrementalAnalysis Perform incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) calculations. dominanceAnalysis Identify dominated extendedly dominated strategies ICER analysis. icer_confidence_intervals Calculate confidence intervals ICERs using bootstrap PSA results. probabilisticAnalysis Perform probabilistic sensitivity analysis using Monte Carlo simulation. psa_advanced_outputs Generate advanced PSA outputs (CEAC, EVPI, net benefit distributions). numSimulations Number Monte Carlo simulations probabilistic analysis. markovAdvanced Enable advanced Markov modeling features. tunnelStates Define tunnel states temporary health states. timeVaryingTransitions Allow transition probabilities change time. ageSpecificTransitions Variables defining age-specific transition rates. chanceNodeMethod Method calculating probabilities chance nodes. riskAdjustment Apply risk adjustment probabilities based patient characteristics. cycleCorrection Apply half-cycle correction accurate discounting Markov models. cohortTrace Generate cohort trace showing population distribution across health states time. cohortSize Size hypothetical cohort trace analysis budget impact modeling. valueOfInformation Perform Expected Value Perfect Information (EVPI) partial EVPI analysis. evpi_parameters Parameters partial EVPI analysis. budgetImpactAnalysis Perform budget impact analysis comparing total costs alternative strategies. targetPopulationSize Size target population budget impact calculations. marketPenetration Expected market penetration rate new intervention. ceacThresholds Cost-effectiveness acceptability curve thresholds (min,max,step). psa_distributions Default probability distribution uncertain parameters PSA. correlatedParameters Account correlations uncertain parameters PSA. correlationMatrix Variables defining correlation structure uncertain parameters. performanceMode Balance speed completeness analysis. memoryOptimization Enable memory-efficient processing large simulations. parallelProcessing Enable parallel processing faster PSA calculations.

code: decisionpanel(   data,   test1,   test1Positive,   test2,   test2Positive,   test3,   test3Positive,   test4,   test4Positive,   test5,   test5Positive,   gold,   goldPositive,   useCosts = FALSE,   testCosts = "",   fpCost = 100,   fnCost = 1000,   strategies = "all",   parallelRules = "any",   customThreshold = 2,   maxTests = 3,   sequentialStop = "positive",   optimizationCriteria = "accuracy",   panelOptimization = "forward",   minImprovement = 0.01,   redundancyThreshold = 0.7,   minSensitivity = 0.8,   minSpecificity = 0.8,   createTree = FALSE,   treeMethod = "costSensitive",   maxDepth = 5,   minSplit = 20,   showAllCombinations = FALSE,   topN = 10,   compareStrategies = TRUE,   bootstrap = FALSE,   bootReps = 1000,   plotTree = TRUE,   plotComparison = TRUE,   plotCostEffect = TRUE,   plotROC = FALSE,   prevalence = 0,   crossValidate = FALSE,   nFolds = 5,   seed = 12345,   showProgress = TRUE )

title: Decision Panel Optimization ‚Äî decisionpanel
text: data data data frame. test1 First diagnostic test variable. test1Positive positive level Test 1. test2 Second diagnostic test variable. test2Positive positive level Test 2. test3 Third diagnostic test variable (optional). test3Positive positive level Test 3. test4 Fourth diagnostic test variable (optional). test4Positive positive level Test 4. test5 Fifth diagnostic test variable (optional). test5Positive positive level Test 5. gold gold standard variable disease classification. goldPositive level gold standard variable indicates disease presence. useCosts Include cost considerations optimization process. testCosts Comma-separated costs test order selected tests. Example: "10,25,50" three tests. fpCost Cost harm associated false positive result. fnCost Cost harm associated false negative result. strategies testing strategies evaluate analysis. parallelRules Rule combining results parallel testing. customThreshold Number positive tests required overall positive result (using custom rule). maxTests Maximum number tests combine strategy. sequentialStop stop testing sequential strategies. optimizationCriteria Primary criterion optimizing test panels. panelOptimization Method building optimal test panels. minImprovement Minimum improvement performance metric required add test panel. redundancyThreshold Correlation threshold tests considered redundant. minSensitivity Minimum sensitivity constraint panel selection. minSpecificity Minimum specificity constraint panel selection. createTree Generate optimal decision tree test sequencing. treeMethod Method constructing decision tree. maxDepth Maximum depth decision tree. minSplit Minimum number observations required split node. showAllCombinations Display performance metrics possible test combinations. topN Number best-performing panels display results. compareStrategies Show comparative analysis different testing strategies. bootstrap Calculate bootstrap confidence intervals performance metrics. bootReps Number bootstrap replications confidence intervals. plotTree Display visual representation optimal decision tree. plotComparison Create comparison plots different testing strategies. plotCostEffect Create cost-effectiveness frontier plot. plotROC Display ROC curves top performing panels. prevalence Known disease prevalence (0 = use sample prevalence). crossValidate Perform k-fold cross-validation panel performance. nFolds Number folds cross-validation. seed Random seed reproducibility bootstrap cross-validation. showProgress Display progress indicators long-running operations like bootstrap cross-validation.

title: Advanced Statistical Tests ‚Äî desctools
text: Advanced statistical tests using functions DescTools package. Includes effect size calculations (Cohen's D), goodness--fit tests (Hosmer-Lemeshow, Anderson-Darling), agreement tests (Barnard, Breslow-Day), trend tests (Cochran-Armitage). Essential clinical research, epidemiological studies, advanced statistical analysis.

title: Advanced Statistical Tests ‚Äî desctools
code: desctools(   data,   effect_size_analysis = FALSE,   group_var = NULL,   continuous_var = NULL,   pooled_sd = TRUE,   hedges_correction = FALSE,   effect_ci_level = 0.95,   goodness_of_fit = FALSE,   fitted_probs = NULL,   observed_outcomes = NULL,   hl_groups = 10,   normality_var = NULL,   categorical_tests = FALSE,   cat_var1 = NULL,   cat_var2 = NULL,   stratum_var = NULL,   ordered_exposure = NULL,   binary_outcome = NULL,   multiple_testing = "none",   show_effect_sizes = TRUE,   show_goodness_tests = TRUE,   show_categorical_tests = TRUE,   show_interpretations = TRUE )

title: Advanced Statistical Tests ‚Äî desctools
text: data data data frame statistical analysis. effect_size_analysis Calculate effect sizes including Cohen's D comparing group means. Essential determining practical significance clinical studies. group_var Categorical variable defining groups effect size comparison. exactly 2 levels Cohen's D calculation. continuous_var Continuous variable effect size calculation (outcome measure). pooled_sd Use pooled standard deviation Cohen's D calculation. Recommended group variances similar. hedges_correction Apply Hedges correction small sample bias effect size calculation. effect_ci_level Confidence level effect size confidence intervals. goodness_of_fit Perform goodness fit tests including Hosmer-Lemeshow test logistic regression models normality tests. fitted_probs Fitted probabilities logistic regression model Hosmer-Lemeshow goodness fit test. observed_outcomes Observed binary outcomes (0/1) Hosmer-Lemeshow test. hl_groups Number groups Hosmer-Lemeshow test. Usually 10 groups provide good balance power stability. normality_var Continuous variable normality testing using Anderson-Darling goodness fit tests. categorical_tests Perform advanced tests categorical data including Barnard's test, Breslow-Day test, Cochran-Armitage trend test. cat_var1 First categorical variable contingency table analysis. cat_var2 Second categorical variable contingency table analysis. stratum_var Stratification variable Breslow-Day test homogeneity odds ratios across strata. ordered_exposure Ordered exposure variable Cochran-Armitage trend test. represent ordered dose exposure levels. binary_outcome Binary outcome variable Cochran-Armitage trend test. multiple_testing Method correcting p-values multiple tests performed. FDR (Benjamini-Hochberg) recommended clinical studies. show_effect_sizes Display effect size calculations including Cohen's D confidence intervals interpretation. show_goodness_tests Display goodness fit test results including Hosmer-Lemeshow normality tests. show_categorical_tests Display results advanced categorical data tests. show_interpretations Provide clinical interpretations guidelines statistical results aid medical decision making.

title: Diagnostic Test Meta-Analysis for Pathology ‚Äî diagnosticmeta
text: data data data frame study Variable containing unique study identifiers true_positives Number true positive results study false_positives Number false positive results study false_negatives Number false negative results study true_negatives Number true negative results study covariate Optional covariate meta-regression analysis bivariate_analysis Perform bivariate random-effects meta-analysis hsroc_analysis Perform hierarchical summary ROC (HSROC) analysis meta_regression Perform meta-regression specified covariate heterogeneity_analysis Perform heterogeneity analysis including -squared Q statistics publication_bias Assess publication bias using Deeks' funnel plot test confidence_level Confidence level meta-analysis results method Method meta-analysis estimation (Note DerSimonian-Laird appropriate bivariate diagnostic meta-analysis) zero_cell_correction Method handling zero cells 2x2 tables. 'none' relies bivariate model (recommended). 'constant' adds 0.5 cells affected studies. 'treatment_arm' adds correction zero cells. 'empirical' uses study-specific corrections. forest_plot Generate forest plot sensitivity specificity sroc_plot Generate summary receiver operating characteristic plot funnel_plot Generate funnel plot publication bias assessment show_individual_studies Display results individual studies summary tables show_interpretation Display clinical interpretation guidelines recommendations show_methodology Display detailed methodology statistical approach information show_analysis_summary Display natural language summary analysis results color_palette Color palette plots - choose color-blind safe options accessibility show_plot_explanations Display detailed explanations plots including interpretation guidance

Standard diagnostic test accuracy meta-analysis data 20 studies, realistic sensitivity/specificity values, moderate heterogeneity, continuous covariates meta-regression. Minimal diagnostic test accuracy meta-analysis data 5 studies, designed testing edge cases small sample sizes convergence behavior. Diagnostic test accuracy meta-analysis data categorical covariate (imaging modality) testing categorical meta-regression subgroup analysis. Diagnostic test accuracy meta-analysis data intentional zero cells several studies, designed testing zero-cell correction methods (none, constant, treatment_arm, empirical). Large diagnostic test accuracy meta-analysis data 50 studies, designed testing computational efficiency, scalability, performance large-scale meta-analyses.
